source_caption_data.pre_caption: This is a static, wide shot of the entrance to the Hotel Provincial. The video is a completely still scenery shot. There is no movement from the camera or any subjects within the frame.
source_caption_data.pre_caption_prompt: The video is a scenery shot. You do not need to describe the subject motion. Just note that briefly in one to three sentences.

source_caption_data.gpt_caption: This is a wide shot of the entrance to the Hotel Provincial. The video features a mostly still scenery shot, with slight shakiness in the camera. The flames within the two gas lamp-style lanterns in the frame are continuously flickering.
source_caption_data.final_caption: This is a wide shot of the entrance to the Hotel Provincial. The video features a mostly still scenery shot, with slight shakiness in the camera. The flames within the two gas lamp-style lanterns in the frame are continuously flickering.

generated_critique: The caption correctly identifies the flickering flames, but it misses other key movements and includes irrelevant information. It incorrectly focuses on the "slight shakiness in the camera," which is a technical aspect of the recording, not the motion of a subject within the scene. The description of the scene as "mostly still" is inaccurate, as in the video, a horse-drawn carriage slowly passes from left to right on the street in front of the hotel, and a person exits the hotel entrance, walking down the steps and out of the frame to the left. A more effective caption would omit the camera's movement and instead describe the continuous flickering of the lamps while also noting the sequential movements of the carriage passing by and the person exiting the building.
revised_caption_by_generated_critique: A wide shot of the entrance to the Hotel Provincial shows flickering flames from the lamps. A horse-drawn carriage slowly passes from left to right on the street in front of the hotel, while a person exits the hotel entrance, walking down the steps and out of the frame to the left.
